comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content: "For many years the ferry at Tal-y-Cafn was the property if Lord Bulkeley, who rented it out at £50 per annum. Passenger, sheep and cattle were conveyed across the river on a heavy floating platform retained in it's position by a stout rope passing through a double set of rollers." www.tal-y-cafn.com/history.asp I can see the rope and a set of rollers on the left hand side of the ferry. But how was the ferry propelled across the river, I can see any signs of oars?

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Thank you Picture Esk, this is the kind of information, redolent of history, that brings any picture to life.

comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content: Having looked at various rope ferries on the Net, I get the impression that most ferryboats were propelled by the ferryman who simply pulled his way across the river using the rope. Looking at the size and weight of the Tay-y-cafn ferry I suspect that there may have been two of them pulling on that rope!
